poem:
**Interlude in the North**

In Iceland's chill,  
a heartbeat thunders—  
fin whale,  
ancient pulse beneath  
our shared sea.  
In measured strokes,  
a pen wavers—  
line of life, or  
license lost.  
Quiet echoes. We wait.  
Ask the white expanse,  
where ocean breathes  
and questions linger  
beyond our grasp.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Iceland’s president urged to intervene over licence for Europe’s last whaler A coalition of conservation and animal welfare groups are urging Iceland’s president to step in and stop any plans the prime minister has to issue a whaling licence to Europe’s last whaler before the Icelandic election at the end of the month. Earlier this year, the country granted a one-year licence to Hvalur to kill more than 100 fin whales this hunting season, despite". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
